topics.body:
Inb4 argument with Thanatos or such, but I read a interesting older article in the nytimes.

The usa might already be already be a multiracial country.  What I mean by this is that if you look at people's family trees and that the majority of people in the usa aren't 100% one race unless they come from another country or their parents come from another country; rather it's that the majority of people identify as one race and they don't know enough about their family tree to specifically identify what percentage of what race they are.

To use an analogy the reason why they use the term "african american" instead of "african" is that if you are african american there's a incredibly high chance that you are to some level caucasian.

On the flip side even though I'm personally only about idunno 40% white I'm still white skin tone (I'm half hispanic, the reason why I know that I'm at most 40% white is because the majority of people on my mother's side came directly from europe in the 1900's).

"Well why is it taking so long for the usa to become multiracial?" Simply put; it's because people for the most part identify as solely one race even knowing full well that they aren't.  To use an analogy the number of hispanics in the usa dropped between consensus because half hispanics wrote them down as caucasian instead cause of their skin tone.


"National geographic actually did a article on what the average usa citizen will look like in 2050":http://mic.com/articles/87359/national-geographic-determined-what-americans-will-look-like-in-2050-and-it-s-beautiful
Before someone starts getting angry about the skin colors keep in mind that currently lighter skin tone is the predominant skin color so genetically speaking if you have a bunch of inter-racial babies then in the long run sure less people will be white but on the other hand less people will have darker skin tones as well.

Tl:dr; if everyone in the usa is a inter-racial then chances are there won't be distinct races anymore; aka there won't be people that look distinctly african american, there won't be people the look distinctly caucasian, etc but rather if you put everyone into a melting pot and popped out a baby.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555fca4d63687236bd0b1000#post_555fca4d63687236bd0b1000
Interesting, but ultimately not something I see ever really influencing people's thinking. Either the person will not give two shits about their personal racial make up because they see it as ultimately irrelevant to their personal identity (treating it as at most an interesting bit of trivia) or they will state that its silly to identify your race with a pie chart (ignoring that identifying yourself by race is already kinda silly) or they'll treat it either as an insult/use it as ammunition in grotesque racist diatribes.
topics.author: 4f41ee04945b701c41002af7

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555fd319636872617c590600#post_555fd319636872617c590600
The reason why I'm going to have the last laugh is because if the usa winds up with a single relative skin tone color then nobody will be able to pull the race card and if everyone has a relatively similar skin tone then racism and "reverse racism" legitimately can't exist.

Person, "I didn't get the job cause of my skin color"
Office workers, "Dude; we're *ALL* the same skin color"
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555fca4d63687236bd0b1000#post_555fca4d63687236bd0b1000
[bq="uc9"]Inb4 argument with Thanatos or such, but I read a interesting older article in the nytimes.

The usa might already be already be a multiracial country.  What I mean by this is that if you look at people's family trees and that the majority of people in the usa aren't 100% one race unless they come from another country or their parents come from another country; rather it's that the majority of people identify as one race and they don't know enough about their family tree to specifically identify what percentage of what race they are.

To use an analogy the reason why they use the term "african american" instead of "african" is that if you are african american there's a incredibly high chance that you are to some level caucasian.

On the flip side even though I'm personally only about idunno 40% white I'm still white skin tone (I'm half hispanic, the reason why I know that I'm at most 40% white is because the majority of people on my mother's side came directly from europe in the 1900's).

"Well why is it taking so long for the usa to become multiracial?" Simply put; it's because people for the most part identify as solely one race even knowing full well that they aren't.  To use an analogy the number of hispanics in the usa dropped between consensus because half hispanics wrote them down as caucasian instead cause of their skin tone.


"National geographic actually did a article on what the average usa citizen will look like in 2050":http://mic.com/articles/87359/national-geographic-determined-what-americans-will-look-like-in-2050-and-it-s-beautiful
Before someone starts getting angry about the skin colors keep in mind that currently lighter skin tone is the predominant skin color so genetically speaking if you have a bunch of inter-racial babies then in the long run sure less people will be white but on the other hand less people will have darker skin tones as well.

Tl:dr; if everyone in the usa is a inter-racial then chances are there won't be distinct races anymore; aka there won't be people that look distinctly african american, there won't be people the look distinctly caucasian, etc but rather if you put everyone into a melting pot and popped out a baby.[/bq]

This is the same with languages in a way. If all the languages all congealed together one day, it would end up developing it's own dialects and ultimately some fraction of the dialects will become distinct enough to become their own language. ~see Scots and English; North Frisian and English; Proto-Indo-European which is a theoretical language that everyone spoke in Europe and India (look that up, I might be wrong)~. Dialects were formed, then the dialects became more and more distinct from each other until they were their own language)\.
topics.author: 37e5b9d66361642500af5e00

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555fd54063687261111e0800#post_555fd54063687261111e0800

You're not having the last laugh my friend. Give it a couple years before they find something else.

I have my bingo card aiming at national fanaticism due being a country encompassing every aspect of mankind, therefore "superior". And Xenophobia over the fact that other people outside the U.S. is going to keep their heritage thus allowing for the fallacy of that being a bad thing.
